# How to train Flux LoRA models

Updated October 9, 2024By [Andrew](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/author/andrew/)Categorized as [Tutorial](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/category/tutorials/) Tagged [ComfyUI](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/tag/comfyui/), [Lora](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/tag/lora/), [Training](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/tag/training/)[25 Commentson How to train Flux LoRA models](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/train-flux-lora/#comments)

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/train-flux-lora-cover.png)

The Flux Dev AI model is a great leap forward in local Diffusion models. It delivers quality surpassing Stable Diffusion 1.5 and [XL](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/sdxl-model) models. Like Stable Diffusion models, you can train [LoRA models](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/lora) on top of Flux to inject custom characters and styles.

In this post, I will provide a Google Colab notebook for training Flux LoRA models. With some setup, you can also run the training workflow locally if you have a good GPU card.

Structured Stable Diffusion courses

Become a Stable Diffusion Pro step-by-step.

See courses

## Requirement

You must be a [site member](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/member) to access the Colab Training notebook and training images below.

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

#### Become a member of this site to see this content

[Become a member](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/member/)

Already a member? [Log in here](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/login/).

You can download the ComfyUI training workflow for free to train locally.

## Software

This is an advanced tutorial for training your own AI model. If you are new to Stable Diffusion or Flux AI models, get the [Quick Start Guide](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/quick_start_guide) for a newbie setup guide.

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

This training workflow uses [ComfyUI](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/comfyui) as GUI. It uses the [ComfyUI Flux Trainer](https://github.com/kijai/ComfyUI-FluxTrainer) custom node with modifications for ease of use, which calls the tried-and-true [Kohya LoRA Trainer](https://github.com/kohya-ss/sd-scripts) under the hood.

The training workflow consists of two parts:

1. Generate captions of the training images automatically.
2. Apply those images to [Flux.1 dev](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/flux-lora/) model to train a custom LoRA model.

## Alternatives

The Flux1.dev model requires more memory to run. Alternatively, you can train:

- [Stable Diffusion 1.5 LoRA model](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/train-lora/)
- [Stable Diffusion 1.5 checkpoint model](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/dreambooth/)
- [Stable Diffusion XL LoRA model](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/train-lora-sdxl/)

## Training on Google Colab

### What you need before you start

#### Google Colab Paid Plan

Due to the demanding computational resources required to train a Flux LoRA model, this notebook requires a [paid Google Colab](https://colab.research.google.com/signup) plan. I use the Colab Pro Plan. Both Pro and Pro+ plan would work.

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

It typically takes ~4.5 hours to train a LoRA on an L4 instance. As of September 2024, the Colab Plus plan costs $10 a month, and you can use an L4 for about 33 hours. So, training a LoRA on Colab will set you back ~$1.40.

#### Training images

To train a Flux LoRA model, you need a set of training images. 10-20 images should do the trick for training a face.

**ONLY PNG images are supported.**

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/image-210-1024x470.png)

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

If you are a [member](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/member) of this site, you can download the example training images below.

#### Become a member of this site to see this content

[Become a member](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/member/)

Already a member? [Log in here](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/login/).

They are all cropped to 1024×1024, but the training notebook supports different sizes.

Tips for good training images:

- The ideal size is 1024×1024. It is OK to use images with different sizes but be sure to include some close to 1024×1024.
- Diversity is the key. You want your subject to be in different scenes, settings, and clothing. Otherwise, the model will be confused about what you are trying to train.
- If you are training a face, include a few high-resolution headshots.
- The default parameters work for 10 – 20 images.

### Step 1: Upload images to Google Drive

Put your training images in the folder **AI_PICS** > **Flux_trainer_input** in your Google Drive. (The folder names are case-sensitive.)

**Note: Only PNG images are supported.**

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-56.png)

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

### Step 2: Run the training notebook

Open the Google Colab Notebook below. You need to be a site member to access it

#### Become a member of this site to see this content

[Become a member](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/member/)

Already a member? [Log in here](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/login/).

Click the Run button to start running the notebook.

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

You will be asked to grant permission to access your Google Drive. Grant permission, as it is necessary to load the training images and save the LoRA model.

It will take a few minutes to load. When it is done, you should see a **URL** and a **Tunnel Password** like the ones below.

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-54.png)

Visit the URL and enter the Tunnel Password to access ComfyUI.

### Step 3: Load the workflow

Download the Easy Flux Trainer workflow below and drop it on the ComfyUI browser page to load it.

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

[Download](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Easy-Flux-LoRA-trainer.json)

You should see the workflow loaded like the screenshot below.

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-55-1024x540.png)

### Step 4: Review input parameters

Review the input parameters in the **Inputs** group.

<iframe frameborder="0" src="https://a0d388e5759e50cc0ade6b8721850d3e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/1030006,22872344705/stablediffusionart/content_7" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="1" height="1" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="private-state-token-redemption" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="b" data-load-complete="true" data-hooks="true" style="box-sizing: inherit; padding: 0px; margin: 0px auto !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; max-width: var(--global--spacing-measure); text-align: center; border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom; height: 250px; width: 300px;"></iframe>

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-59.png)

- **LoRA name**: The name of your LoRA. Pick a name that matches what you are training for.
- **Token**: The trigger keyword of your LoRA. Put this in the prompt when using your LoRA.
- **Image Input Path**: The folder path of your training images in Google Drive. You don’t need to change this unless you have put the images in another folder.
- **LoRA Output Path**: The folder where the LoRA model will be stored.
- **Test prompts**: The prompts that will be used to test the LoRA model during training. The prompts are separated by a vertical line (|). Include the token in the prompt if you want to test the training. Include a prompt to test not using the token to monitor over-training.

### Step 5: Generate captions

The workflow can generate captions automatically for your training images using the [BLIP Vision-language model.](https://github.com/salesforce/BLIP)

In the **Step Selector** Input node, set

- **Enable Captioning**: Yes
- **Enable Training**: No

<iframe frameborder="0" src="https://a0d388e5759e50cc0ade6b8721850d3e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/1030006,22872344705/stablediffusionart/content_8" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="0" height="267" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="private-state-token-redemption" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="c" data-load-complete="true" data-hooks="true" style="box-sizing: inherit; padding: 0px; margin: 0px auto !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; max-width: var(--global--spacing-measure); text-align: center; border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom; min-width: 100%;"></iframe>

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-60.png)

Click **Queue Prompt** to start captioning.

After it is done, you will see text files with the same name of the training images created in the image input folder.

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-61.png)

<iframe frameborder="0" src="https://a0d388e5759e50cc0ade6b8721850d3e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/1030006,22872344705/stablediffusionart/content_9" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="1" height="1" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="private-state-token-redemption" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="d" data-load-complete="true" data-hooks="true" style="box-sizing: inherit; padding: 0px; margin: 0px auto !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; max-width: var(--global--spacing-measure); text-align: center; border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom; height: 90px; width: 728px;"></iframe>

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

You can optionally revise them to better match the images.

### Step 6: Start training

Now, we get to the fun part of training.

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-62.png)

In the **Step Selector** input node, set:

- **Enable Captioning**: No
- **Enable Training**: Yes

The workflow is configured to test and save the LoRA with the prompts you specified every 400 steps. You should see 4 blocks of **Flux Train Loop** nodes like the one shown below.

<iframe frameborder="0" src="https://a0d388e5759e50cc0ade6b8721850d3e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/1030006,22872344705/stablediffusionart/content_10" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="1" height="1" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="private-state-token-redemption" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="e" data-load-complete="true" data-hooks="true" style="box-sizing: inherit; padding: 0px; margin: 0px auto !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; max-width: var(--global--spacing-measure); text-align: center; border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom; height: 90px; width: 728px;"></iframe>

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-63.png)

You can change the steps values to change intervals between saving/testing the LoRA.

Click **Queue Prompt** to run the workflow.

Running on an L4 GPU instance (default) takes ~1.5 hours per 400 steps. If you can visualize the training results in ComfyUI like below.

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-64-1024x554.png)

<iframe frameborder="0" src="https://a0d388e5759e50cc0ade6b8721850d3e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/1030006,22872344705/stablediffusionart/content_11" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="1" height="1" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="private-state-token-redemption" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="f" data-load-complete="true" data-hooks="true" style="box-sizing: inherit; padding: 0px; margin: 0px auto !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; max-width: var(--global--spacing-measure); text-align: center; border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom; height: 90px; width: 728px;"></iframe>

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

If you don’t see the images, you can find them in the **samples** folder inside the LoRA output folder. The default output folder is **AI_PICS** > **Flux_trainer_output** in your Google Drive.

It typically takes 1,000-1,500 steps to train a LoRA for Flux.1 Dev.

Feel free to stop the workflow early if you have achieved the results already.

### Step 7: Test the LoRA

Follow the tutorial [How to use LoRA with Flux AI model](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/flux-lora/) to test your LoRA.

In addition to adding the LoRA, remember to add the token (trigger keyword) to the prompt. (“emma” in this tutorial)

<lora:flux_emma_rank16_bf16:1> emma skiing outfit, snow, smile, brown hair, light, safety goggle

![img](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/image-66-1024x499.png)

<iframe frameborder="0" src="https://a0d388e5759e50cc0ade6b8721850d3e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/1030006,22872344705/stablediffusionart/content_12" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="1" height="1" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="private-state-token-redemption" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="g" data-load-complete="true" data-hooks="true" style="box-sizing: inherit; padding: 0px; margin: 0px auto !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; max-width: var(--global--spacing-measure); text-align: center; border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom; height: 90px; width: 728px;"></iframe>

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

## Training locally on Windows/Linux

You can use this workflow locally, although I won’t support it.

[Download](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Easy-Flux-LoRA-trainer.json)

### Software setup

It is better to [install a fresh copy of ComfyUI](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/how-to-install-comfyui/) just for running this training because the workflow has a low tolerance in conflicts.

Install [ComfyUI Manager](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/comfyui-manager-install/).

<iframe frameborder="0" src="https://a0d388e5759e50cc0ade6b8721850d3e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/1030006,22872344705/stablediffusionart/content_13" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="1" height="1" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="private-state-token-redemption" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="h" data-load-complete="true" data-hooks="true" style="box-sizing: inherit; padding: 0px; margin: 0px auto !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; max-width: var(--global--spacing-measure); text-align: center; border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom; height: 90px; width: 728px;"></iframe>

![img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

Drop the workflow to the ComfyUI browser page and install the missing custom nodes using the ComfyUI Manager.

I am not able to keep up with the breaking changes in the custom nodes. So, the workflow only works for particular versions of ComfyUI and custom nodes.

Use `git checkout` to check out the following commits accordingly.

- ComfyUI: `9c5fca75f46f7b9f18c07385925f151a7629a94f`
- ComfyUI-Manager: `ce874d5c624d5713e7db334d1e0c50aeddb90d82`
- was-node-suite-comfyui: `bb34bd429ab74a22a7f58551429a0f3046e1464e`
- rgthree-comfy: `cae8e2ad28ddb933a916b852d26b95726f60529f`
- ComfyUI-KJNodes: `7aa591b3a64a3f83ec2c3e92758d0bb0926a6fe0`
- ComfyUI-FluxTrainer: `c3aa4ea889153519f7be40636b44d5a03a060816`
- Image-Captioning-in-ComfyUI: `9b24deea8eef830da059aa91cac9690ecde19fda`

For example, run the following under the `ComfyUI` folder.

```
git checkout 9c5fca75f46f7b9f18c07385925f151a7629a94f
```

And the following under the `custom_nodes\ComfyUI-FluxTrainer` folder.

```
git checkout c3aa4ea889153519f7be40636b44d5a03a060816
```

Follow the [Flux tutorial for ComfyUI](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/flux-comfyui/) to download the Flux.1 Dev UNet model, text encoders, and VAE.
